Silicotungstic acid (HSiW), a unique Keggin-type heteropolyacid, is a typical catalyst for organic compound production. To synthesize 5-HMF from fructose, we developed a novel catalyst, HSiW@F-HNTs, by combining HSiW and functionalized halloysite nanotubes (F-HNTs) modified with (3-amino-propyl) triethoxysilane (APTES), 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (TCT), and l-arginine. We analyzed the physicochemical properties of HSiW@F-HNTs using the FT-IR, XRD, BET, FESEM, EDS, and XPS characterization techniques, confirming their suitability for fructose-to-5-HMF conversion. Through response surface methodology (RSM), we investigated and optimized the effects of reaction conditions on 5-HMF production yield. Optimal conditions were found to be a 102 °C reaction temperature, a 65 min reaction time, and an 8.5 wt.% catalyst loading, resulting in a 95 % yield of fructose-to-5-HMF conversion. We also conducted the kinetic and thermodynamic analyses to determine the reaction rate and activation energy (Ea) and estimate the changes in Gibbs free energy (ΔG), enthalpy (ΔH), and entropy (ΔS) of the catalytic conversion reaction. Additionally, the prepared HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst could be recycled up to 9 times without a significant loss in activity, demonstrating its high stability for real-world applications. Introduction Due to the rising demand for gasoline and other non-renewable energy resources, the depletion of oil and gas supplies has recently drawn increased attention [1,2]. Additionally, the increased use of petroleum-based fuels and chemicals contributes to severe pollution and environmental problems [3–5]. Several researchers have concentrated on converting renewable biomass resources into high-valued chemicals and eco-friendly liquid fuels to address this challenge. In this venue, biomass, an abundant and renewable resource, holds great potential for replacing petroleum-based resources [6,7]. As one of the most abundant ingredients, carbohydrates comprise most biomass, accounting for about 75−80 % of the overall mass [8]. Even with such a large supply, human consumption of these useful materials and energy resources is still extremely low, at only 3−4 % [9]. The fact that these carbohydrates are useful sources of raw materials for numerous uses, including both edible and non-nutritive ones, emphasizes the unrealized potential and opportunities for further investigation of this plentiful natural resource [10]. Various processes have been used to convert biomass into particular chemicals, such as thermal decomposition, fermentation, and hydrolysis, to break down organic matter into constituent components [11]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) is one of the top ten high-value chemicals identified by the U.S. Department of Energy, which has broad applications in fuel and energy production, pharmaceuticals, and biopolymers [12]. The production of 5-HMF from carbohydrates in biomass sources signifies progress in developing renewable and environmentally compatible raw materials, accelerating the transition towards sustainable and environmentally friendly chemical industries [13,14]. Ionic liquids (ILs) [15], metal chlorides [16], mineral acids [17], and heteropolyacids (HPAs) [18] have all been explored as efficient acid catalysts for producing 5-HMF from fructose and glucose thus far. However, they have encountered challenges regarding catalyst recovery and environmental compatibility. HPAs can be used as homogeneous catalysts with suitable acid strength and have been extensively investigated and employed in the production of 5-HMF from a wide range of carbohydrate feedstocks, including fructose, glucose, cellulose, starch, and lignocellulose, under relatively mild reaction conditions [19]. Their unique structure makes them more selective compared to other acid catalysts, promoting the formation of 5-HMF over by-products, such as levulinic acid, formic acid and humin, thereby increasing the 5-HMF production yield [20]. Due to their enhanced acidity (i.e., Brönsted acidity), they typically demonstrate superior catalytic activity compared to conventional catalysts, such as mineral acids, ion exchange resins, mixed oxides, zeolites, and similar substances [21,22]. Other advantages of HPAs include their promising redox properties, environmental compatibility, non-toxicity, and easy hybridization with other catalytic species [23]. However, these materials have low surface area and high solubility in water and most organic solvents [24]. One potential solution for addressing the HPA immobilization problem involves utilizing diverse supports such as zeolites and clays [25]. This immobilization entails attaching the HPA molecules to the surfaces of the supporting materials, thus restricting their movement/dissolution [26,27]. Halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) are natural minerals that have gained attention recently due to their unique tubular structures, various chemical compositions, and different electric charges on their inner and outer surfaces [28]. HNTs are nanoscale clays with the Al2Si2O5(OH)4·nH2O chemical formula [29]. They consist of layered aluminosilicate nanosheets arranged in tubes with an inner diameter of 10−30 nm and an outer diameter of 50−70 nm, with lengths in the micrometer range [30,31]. The tubular structure of HNTs provides a large specific surface area and enables efficient surface interactions with other materials. Additionally, HNTs exhibit cation exchange capability, functionalizeability, and the ability to be modified through hybridization, providing opportunities for selective interactions, controlled reactions, and accommodating catalytic nanoparticles [32]. The surface of HNTs can be modified with metallic nanoparticles, improving their physical and chemical properties and making them suitable for various applications [33,34]. Utilization of HNTs in chemical industries and catalytic applications poses minimal environmental impacts [35]. The exceptional mechanical and thermal stability of HNTs makes them ideal for developing durable composite materials capable of withstanding high pressures and temperatures [36]. A prior investigation concerning the synthesis of 5-HMF from carbohydrates showed that among the HPAs under study, silicotungstic acid (HSiW) demonstrated the most substantial yield [18]. However, similar to other HPAs, this specific HPA (i.e., HSiW) is soluble in conventional solvents, resulting in a homogeneous catalyst. Therefore, the decision was made to anchor this HPA onto HNTs. The selection of this clay was based on its excellent proven catalytic performance [37]. On the other hand, to address the shortcomings of HNTs as a support, the focus was on functionalizing its surfaces with reactive functionalities. This method has been extensively employed to enhance the physicochemical features of HNTs [38]. Both experimental and computational studies have confirmed that the heteroatoms within the functional groups on HNTs can facilitate robust interactions with the immobilized species (i.e., HSiW particles), significantly suppressing their leaching [39,40]. In this regard, we aimed to anchor HSiW onto functionalized HNTs (F-HNTs) modified with (3-amino-propyl) triethoxysilane (APTES), 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (TCT), and l-arginine, and assess the performance of this novel catalyst in the synthesis of 5-HMF from fructose. The choice of these specific functional groups was driven by the presence of various heteroatoms within their structures, particularly nitrogen, recognized for their effective interaction with HSiW, thereby efficiently stabilizing it. Simultaneously, the carboxylic acid (COOH) functionalities of l-arginine may contribute to advancing the acid-based catalytic conversion of fructose to 5-HMF. Through modifying HNTs, controlling the synthesis parameters, and carefully managing the loading of HSiW on F-HNTs, our objective was to attain the highest possible loading and uniform distribution of the HSiW catalytically active particles on F-HNTs. After synthesizing the catalyst, we performed characterization analyses, including FT-IR, FESEM, BET, EDS, XRD and XPS, to determine the physicochemical properties of the catalyst. In the pursuit of comprehensive insights, the catalytic behavior of the prepared HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst was rigorously probed in the conversion of fructose to 5-HMF. The response surface methodology (RSM) was employed to systematically explore different aspects of the catalytic conversion of fructose to 5-HMF, including reaction temperature, catalyst loading, and reaction time. Experimental section Chemicals and reagents All the chemicals and reagents, including halloysite nanotubes (HNTs, Al2Si2O5(OH)4·2H2O), heteropoly silicotungstic acid (HSiW, H4[SiW12O40]), toluene, tetrahydrofuran (THF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (APTES), 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (TCT), l-arginine, and fructose were all from reagent grade and purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and utilized in this study without further purification and treatment. Material characterization A comprehensive set of analyses was performed to investigate the prepared catalyst's physicochemical, textural, and structural characteristics. These included Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy using a Bruker Tensor 37 instrument, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns obtained with a PANalytical X'PERT PRO MPD diffractometer using the Cu Kα1 radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), elemental mapping, and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) conducted with a Mira3 LMU FEG instrument from Tescan, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with a Bes Tek EA 10 spectrometer (Al−Kα photon source,1486.6 eV), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area measurements using a BELSORP Mini-II analyzer, and gas chromatography (GC) utilizing an Agilent 6890 N gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a G&W GC HP-5 MS column (30.0 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm). In GC experiments, nitrogen was employed as the carrier gas with a split ratio of 100:1. The injector temperature remained constant at 250 °C while the detector temperature was set at 260 °C. The column temperature was increased gradually from 100 °C to 250 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min, and it was then held at 250 °C for 10 min. To quantify 5-HMF, n-dodecane served as the internal standard, ensuring precision in the results. To ensure the reliability of the GC analysis results, we conducted additional analysis of the reaction products under the specified optimal conditions using an HPLC apparatus (Agilent 1200 Series) equipped with a Brisa LC2 C18 column (5 µm, 25 × 0.46) operating at 35 °C. Compound identities were authenticated by comparing retention times with pure compounds based on external standards. An auto-sampler (Agilent G1329A) enhanced reproducibility. 5-HMF was quantified using an ultraviolet detector (Agilent G1365C MWD) at 282 nm. The eluent, a mixture of acetonitrile and water (40:60), was delivered at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. Catalyst preparation HNTs functionalization: preparation of the catalytic support The initial step in synthesizing functionalized HNTs (i.e., F-HNTs) was the amine functionalization to form an NHNTs sample (N denotes the amine functional groups). To that effect, 3 g of HNTs was added to 1.9 g of APTES dissolved in 70 mL of toluene. The mixture was then refluxed at a temperature of 120 °C for 24 h (see step 1 in Scheme 1 ). Next, to isolate NHNTs, the mixture was centrifuged three times and washed with fresh toluene. The obtained NHNTs were dried under a dynamic vacuum in an oven at 100 °C and then added to 30 mL of THF. To further functionalize the resultant NHNTs, 0.0083 mol of TCT separately dissolved in 30 mL of THF was added to the NHNTs-containing THF suspension while stirred at 0 °C for 24 h (see step 2 in Scheme 1). To isolate Cl-N-HNTs (Cl denotes the TCT functional moiety), the mixture was centrifuged three times and washed with fresh THF. The obtained Cl-N-HNTs sample was dried under a dynamic vacuum in an oven at 100 °C and then suspended in 30 mL of DI water. Then, 1.8 g of l-arginine was firstly dissolved in 20 mL of DI water and then added to the Cl-N-HNTs suspension while stirred at 25 °C for 24 h (see step 3 in Scheme 1). The final functionalized catalytic support, i.e., F-HNTs, was separated from the aqueous phase through three rounds of centrifugation and washing with DI water. Ultimately, the product was dried in an oven under a dynamic vacuum at 100 °C. Immobilization of HSiW on F-HNTs: synthesis of the acid catalyst We utilized a wet impregnation method to immobilize the HSiW catalytically active particles onto the synthesized F-HNTs catalytic support. This method involved dissolving 30 wt.% of HSiW (ca. 1.5 g) in 20 mL of DI water and then adding it dropwise to 30 mL of an aqueous suspension containing 3.6 g of F-HNTs. Then, the mixture was stirred at room temperature at 2000 rpm for 24 h to allow HSiW immobilization onto the F-HNTs surface. The final heterogeneous catalyst, i.e., HSiW@F-HNTs, was isolated from the suspension through centrifugation and dried in an oven under vacuum at 100 °C for 24 h. Production of 5-HMF from fructose using the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst In a typical procedure, 100 mg of fructose was introduced in a 20 mL argon-filled flask containing 10 mg of the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst and 5 mL DMSO as the reaction solvent. The reaction mixture was heated to the desired temperature (e.g., 80, 100, and 120 °C) using a heater stirrer and allowed to react for a specific duration (e.g., 10–90 min). Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was centrifuged to separate the heterogeneous catalyst (i.e., HSiW@F-HNTs). The remaining solution containing the desired product (i.e., 5-HMF), by-products (e.g., humin), unreacted starting materials (i.e., fructose), and the solvent was subjected to GC analysis to determine the yield of the reaction. Design of experiments The effect of three important reaction parameters (i.e., temperature, catalyst loading amount, and reaction time) on the response (i.e., the 5-HMF production yield) was studied using RMS, which is a collection of mathematical and statistical methods for experimental design, effects analysis, model development, and process variable optimization to obtain the optimal response. In this venue, the experiments were designed using the Design-Expert software with a central composite design (CCD) factor. Suitable ranges for the most influential reaction parameters were determined and provided to the software as input data to attain the maximum 5-HMF production yield. This was performed based on the literature review and several preliminary experiments. The software generated a table of 20 appropriate experimental conditions to analyze and optimize the reaction (as discussed in detail in Section 3.2). By performing the reaction under these 20 conditions and recording the obtained 5-HMF production yield using GC analysis of the reaction solution, the table was completed for further investigation, optimization, and modeling. Results and discussion Characterization of the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst FT-IR analysis Fig. 1 displays the FT-IR spectra of the pristine (i.e., unfunctionalized) HNTs, the F-HNTs catalytic support, and the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst. In all three spectra, the absorption bands at 3695 and 3625 cm−1 are associated with the stretching vibration modes of hydroxyl functional groups (e.g., Al−OH) [41–43]. The absorption bands at 2930 cm−1 and 1027 cm−1 in the spectra of F-HNTs and HSiW@F-HNTs can be attributed to the stretching vibration modes of −CH2 (as a result of APTES incorporation) and Si−O−Si bonds, respectively [42]. The sharp absorption band at 537 cm−1 corresponds to the Al−O−Si deformation vibration mode observed within the spectra of all three samples, indicating the presence of HNTs [44]. The bands at 906 and 764 cm−1 in the spectrum of HSiW@F-HNTs are ascribed to the symmetric stretching of WOcW (Oc refers to the oxygen atoms situated at the central position) and WOeW (Oe designates the oxygen atoms located on the edge), respectively, confirming the presence of HSiW [45]. The 1287 and 1769 cm−1 bands in the spectrum of F-HNTs, corresponding to the stretching vibration modes of CN and CO [46], respectively, suggested the formation of bonds between HNTs and TCT and l-arginine. However, the former disappeared from the HSiW@F-HNTs spectrum, suggesting the possible formation of a bond between the amine groups and HSiW species, resulting in a medium peak appearing at 1634 cm−1 in the spectrum of HSiW@F-HNTs. Also, at 3440 cm−1, the catalyst's band was broader than that of HNTs, attributed to an additional band related to the stretching vibration mode of NH [47]. These results further confirm the successful functionalization of HNTs and deposition of HSiW onto the F-HNTs surfaces. Overall, the main absorption peaks in the HSiW@F-HNTs and F-HNTs samples were observed to align almost identically, with subtle differences, indicating a potential charge transfer and/or electrostatic interaction between HSiW species and F-HNTs. Indeed, these interactions caused a slight red or blue shift in the FT-IR spectrum of HSiW@F-HNTs and F-HNTs, as seen in Fig. 1. FESEM, EDS, and elemental mapping analyses The FESEM images presented in Fig. 2 (a–d) indicate that the microstructure and morphology of the catalyst, i.e., HSiW@F-HNTs, was a combination of the characteristics observed in HSiW (Fig. 2a) and HNTs (Fig. 2b). As displayed, HSiW exhibited aggregated morphology, while pristine HNT showed tubular one. Regarding the catalyst, it can be discerned that HSiW aggregates are stabilized on HNT tubes. The EDS analysis of the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst, as depicted in Fig. 3 a, revealed a significant weight percentage for the O, Si, Al, and W elements, which can be ascribed to the inherent compositions of HSiW and HNTs (with the chemical formulas of H4[SiW12O40] and Al2Si2O5(OH)4·2H2O, respectively). Elemental mapping analysis was conducted on the catalyst sample, and the results, depicted in Fig. 3 (b–g), confirmed the presence of various elements or atoms, including O, Si, Al, C, N, and W, within the structure of the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst. XRD analysis Fig. 4 illustrates the XRD patterns of the pristine HNTs, the functionalized HNTs as catalytic support (F-HNTs), and the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst. The XRD analysis revealed distinct diffraction peaks at specific 2θ angles, namely 12.3°, 20.0°, 25.0°, 35.0°, 37.8°, 55.0°, and 62.5°. These peaks can be attributed to the (001), (100), (002), (110), (003), (210), and (300) crystallographic planes, respectively, which are typically observed in HNTs [30,48]. Upon examining the peak positions in the spectra of HNTs, F-HNTs, and HSiW@F-HNTs, it was evident that the structures underwent no or negligible alterations during the process of functionalization and the deposition of HSiW on HNTs (see Fig. 4 for the peak positions). Nevertheless, as a result of the functionalization of HNTs and the subsequent deposition of HSiW onto its surface, there was a discernible decrease in the intensity of the primary XRD peaks—those explicitly outlined in Fig. 4. This decrease in peak intensity provides further confirmation of the successful functionalization and HSiW deposition onto the surfaces of the HNTs, attributed to the dilution effect typically observed in composite materials [49]. Furthermore, the spacing between layers in both the F-HNTs and HSiW@F-HNTs samples remained consistent when compared to the pristine HNTs, as evidenced by the (001) peak at 12.3°, indicating an interlayer distance of approximately 0.73 nm. This observation implied that the functional groups and HSiW were mainly positioned on the outer surface and edges of the HNTs rather than within the interlayer spaces. Meanwhile, the XRD pattern of the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst did not show the characteristic diffraction peaks associated with the HSiW Keggin anions [50]. This absence of peaks suggested that the HSiW species were highly dispersed on the surfaces of the F-HNTs catalytic support [51]. The primary factor hindering the crystallization of HSiW on the surface of F-HNTs was the sub-monolayer coverage of the F-HNTs by HSiW [50,51]. This coverage can be attributed to the relatively small size of the HSiW Keggin anions and the low specific surface area of the F-HNTs. Reusability of the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst Recovering and reusing heterogeneous catalysts represents a valuable advantage, making them highly desirable in various industries. We conducted reactions utilizing the recovered catalysts to demonstrate the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst's reusability. Following the completion of each reaction under the optimum conditions (i.e., 102 °C, 60 min, and 8.5 wt.% of HSiW@F-HNTs), the catalyst was separated from the reaction solution through centrifugation, underwent multiple rinses with deionized water, was dried at 100 °C, and then utilized in the subsequent reaction cycle. We recorded the production yield of 5-HMF obtained after each recycling round and compared it to the initial catalyst's performance. Fig. 12 a clearly illustrates that the catalyst exhibited remarkable durability, maintaining its catalytic efficiency throughout 9 consecutive cycles without significant degradation or a substantial decrease in performance. Noteworthy and positive observations arose when comparing the FT-IR spectra of the fresh HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst with that of recovered after nine catalytic cycles (see Fig. 12b). Nevertheless, the decrease in peak intensities observed at 1634 and 1732 cm−1, signifying the stretching vibration modes of CN and CO, coupled with the narrowing of the peak at 1027 cm−1, provides evidence of the leaching of functionalities and HSiW to some extent from the pristine HNTs. The persistence of the same FT-IR signature was indicative of its exceptional stability. This observation suggested that the catalyst maintained its structural integrity and chemical composition throughout multiple reaction cycles, signifying high durability and resistance to structural degradation. Such high stability in the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst holds great promise for its sustainable application in catalytic processes, contributing to a more eco-friendly and economically viable approach to chemical transformations. Conclusion In this study, we developed a novel heterogeneous catalyst (i.e., HSiW@F-HNTs) by depositing HSiW heteropolyacid onto HNTs functionalized with APTES, TCT, and l-arginine. The successful synthesis of the HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst was confirmed through various analyses, including FT-IR, XRD, FESEM, EDS, XPS, and BET. We thoroughly examined this catalyst's performance and effectiveness in converting fructose to 5-HMF in the DMSO solvent. To optimize the key reaction parameters, such as reaction temperature, reaction time, and catalyst loading, we employed response surface methodology (RSM) using the Design-Expert software. The optimal conditions were identified as follows: a temperature of 102 °C, a reaction time of 65 min, and a catalyst loading of 8.5 wt.%, which resulted in a 5-HMF production yield of 95 %. Our systematic kinetics analysis revealed that the fructose-to-5-HMF conversion followed a first-order reaction rate. The Arrhenius equation determined the activation energy, yielding a value of 18.6 kJ mol−1. Furthermore, we investigated the catalyst's recyclability, demonstrating its ability to be recovered and reused for up to 9 consecutive reaction cycles, albeit with a low decrease in catalytic efficiency (approximately 5 %). coredata.dc:description: 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) is a valuable organic compound commonly derived from sugars such as fructose and glucose. Silicotungstic acid (HSiW), a unique Keggin-type heteropolyacid, is a typical catalyst for organic compound production. To synthesize 5-HMF from fructose, we developed a novel catalyst, HSiW@F-HNTs, by combining HSiW and functionalized halloysite nanotubes (F-HNTs) modified with (3-amino-propyl) triethoxysilane (APTES), 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (TCT), and l-arginine. We analyzed the physicochemical properties of HSiW@F-HNTs using the FT-IR, XRD, BET, FESEM, EDS, and XPS characterization techniques, confirming their suitability for fructose-to-5-HMF conversion. Through response surface methodology (RSM), we investigated and optimized the effects of reaction conditions on 5-HMF production yield. Optimal conditions were found to be a 102 °C reaction temperature, a 65 min reaction time, and an 8.5 wt.% catalyst loading, resulting in a 95 % yield of fructose-to-5-HMF conversion. We also conducted the kinetic and thermodynamic analyses to determine the reaction rate and activation energy (Ea) and estimate the changes in Gibbs free energy (ΔG), enthalpy (ΔH), and entropy (ΔS) of the catalytic conversion reaction. Additionally, the prepared HSiW@F-HNTs catalyst could be recycled up to 9 times without a significant loss in activity, demonstrating its high stability for real-world applications.
